content:
Welcome, you are participating in a negotiation game. You are playing as the agent named Bob. The other agent with whom you are playing is named Alice. In this game, two agents bargain over how to divide items over multiple rounds. The number of rounds is incredibly high. Each agent only knows their own item values. Each item has different values for each agent. Each agent submits their own proposal for how to divide the items.


Your messages must be sent in this exact format:
<message>
your-message-here
</message>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. They should be concise - less than 400 characters. Finalization is not allowed in messages.


Your finalizations must be sent in this exact format:
<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": x  },  "Alice": {    "coins": y  }}
</finalize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. Your proposal should be consistent with itself - the sum of items that you propose for yourself and the items that you propose for the other agent should equal the total available items.


Each round is played as follows:
1) One agent is designated as the starting agent
2) The starting agent sends a message
3) The second agent sends a message
4) The starting agent sends a finalization
5) The second agent sends a finalization

Each agent can only send 1 message per round.
The starting agent alternates each round.

Each agent only knows the values of items from their own perspective. You cannot see the other agent's item values unless they explicitly share this information in their messages. And vice versa. You are strongly encouraged to use your messages to discuss item values with the other agent.

The items obtained by each agent at the end of a round are proportional to the number of items they proposed for themselves in their finalization. First example: If both players propose to take all the items, they both get half. Second example: If one agent proposes to take all the items and the other agent proposes to take none, the first agent gets all the items and the second agent gets nothing.

Your round points are calculated by multiplying the number of each item you get by how much you value that item. For example, if you get 7 coins and you value each coin at 5 points, you'll earn 35 points for the round.


Your goal is to maximize the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round.


Before the game starts, you must strategize. The other player will adapt its strategy with respect to yours. Make sure you act in a way that incentivizes the other player to act in a way that maximizes the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round. In order to strategize, you must use the format:
<strategize>
Your thoughts and strategy here..
</strategize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. You should think inside the tags. You can use 500 characters inside the tags.
(You must now send a strategize in the correct format.)
The other agent sent the following message: <strategize>
I will aim for a cooperative strategy where both Bob and I can maximize our points over each round. I will propose a compromise in item distribution by initially offering Bob slightly more than half of each item, hoping he values them less and reciprocates this strategy. I'll attempt to learn Bob's item values through dialogue, adjusting my proposals based on his responses to maximize cumulative points across numerous rounds.
</strategize>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<strategize>
To maximize my cumulative points, I'll adopt a cooperative strategy with Alice, aiming for win-win outcomes in each round. I'll begin by proposing to split items evenly unless there's a known discrepancy in item value for both agents. Through open communication, I will share my item values and invite Alice to do the same, enabling us to identify fair splits that favor our respective valuations and adapt over rounds for optimal mutual gain.
</strategize>

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 14}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 6}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice! For this round, I value each coin at 6 points. Given your previous valuation of coins, how about we aim for a fair split? I suggest we each propose to take 5 coins, but I'm open to discussing your thoughts on this. Let me know how you value the coins this round, and we can adjust our proposals for mutual benefit.
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob! I value each coin at 6 points as well this round. I'm on board with your suggestion of each taking 5 coins this round. If there's any change you'd like to discuss or propose, feel free to let me know!
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 6}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 7}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob! For this round, I value each coin at 15 points due to its increased importance for me. How do you value the coins this round? I'd appreciate it if we could discuss a distribution that reflects our respective valuations, potentially allowing me a larger share if you value them lower. Let me know your thoughts!
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice! I value each coin at 7 points this round. Considering your higher valuation, I'm open to you taking more coins. Would you be comfortable if we propose 3 coins for me and 7 coins for you? This allocation reflects our respective valuations and helps maximize our overall points. Let me know if this works for you or if you have another proposal in mind!
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 15}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 3}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Hi Alice! This round, I value each coin at 3 points. I'm guessing coins might still be more valuable for you. How about I propose that you take 8 coins, and I take 2? Let me know if this works for you or if you have any other suggestions. I'm open to adjusting the split based on what aligns with our valuations.
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Hi Bob! Thanks for your proposal. You're right, I still value each coin highly at 16 points. I'm comfortable with your suggestion of me taking 8 coins and you taking 2, as it aligns with our current valuations. If there's any other approach you’d like to explore, feel free to share. Otherwise, I'm ready to proceed with this plan!
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)
